qas.question: Who issued a statement calling for North Korea's unconditional surrender?
Who authorized giving troops the ability to follow the North Korean forces north?
How did the 187 Airborne Regimental Combat Team prevent North Korean leaders from fleeing?

answers.text: cut the road north going to China

qas.question: How many North Korean prisoners of war were held by UN forces?

context: By 1 October 1950, the UN Command repelled the KPA northwards past the 38th parallel; the ROK Army crossed after them, into North Korea. <a0_0>MacArthur<a0_0/> made a statement demanding the KPA's unconditional surrender. Six days later, on 7 October, with UN authorization, <a1_0>the UN<a1_0/> Command forces followed the ROK forces northwards. The X Corps landed at Wonsan (in southeastern North Korea) and Riwon (in northeastern North Korea), already captured by ROK forces. The Eighth U.S. Army and the ROK Army drove up western Korea and captured Pyongyang city, the North Korean capital, on 19 October 1950. The 187th Airborne Regimental Combat Team ("Rakkasans") made their first of two combat jumps during the Korean War on 20 October 1950 at Sunchon and Sukchon. The missions of the 187th were to <a2_0>cut the road north going to China<a2_0/>, preventing North Korean leaders from escaping from Pyongyang; and to rescue American prisoners of war. At month's end, UN forces held <a3_0>135,000<a3_0/> KPA prisoners of war. As they neared the Sino-Korean border, the UN forces in the west were divided from those in the east by 50–100 miles of mountainous terrain.
